chargeHist.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal)

result.execSummary:
The defendant Matthew John Johnson was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Bail Jumping-Felony, a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 946.49(1)(b).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Defendant Matthew John Johnson in court.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant's motion to withdraw the plea.  Defendant wishes to proceed today on the motion.  Court reviews affidavit on file.  State does not object to defendant signing the affidavit previously filed.  Defendant reviews and signs Affidavit filed 4/25/2016 as attachment to motion.  Marked exh. 1, signed affidavit.  State has no objection.  Exh 1 received by the court.  State argue motion and believes the defendant can go forward.  State reviews and recites if motion is granted, case goes back to before the plea.  Court reviews motion, affidavit and history of case.  Court finds defendant had a full understanding of the proceedings and procedures.  Attorney assistance not ineffective.  Court rules to deny the motion.  Court questions reporting to jail today to start sentence.  Defendant notes the appeal process.  Court reviews and explains.  Grants stay pending appeal, however low likelihood of success on appeal.  Stay in place for two more weeks.  Report to Sauk County Jail on Sept 29, 2016 at 6:30 p.m. to begin serving the sentence previously imposed.
Motion hearing on September 15, 2016 at 10:00 am.

Defendant Matthew John Johnson in court.  Linda Ann Hoffman appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court notes that the COA grant second extension to 9/30/2016.  Court schedules hearing on post-conviction motion.  Hearing will be held as scheduled and DE will have to appear and make his argument whether he has counsel or not.  Court explains process to DE re: him possibly having to report to jail if his motion is denied.  Motion hearing scheduled for September 15, 2016 at 10:00 am.
from Court of Appeals extending time to decide post-conviction motion to 9/30/2016

Defendant Matthew John Johnson in court.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Motion to get atty. Evidentiary hearing on defendant's motion for post-conviction relief.  State may file written response by 8/15/16.  State states DE had until 9/1/16 to get an atty. by Judge Klicko Br. 2.  Court is not sure if can appt. atty.  State state 3 other cases are involved in this particular DE's status right now.  Court of Appeals extended the deadline until tomorrow.  Court states if allows DE to withdraw plea all the other charges/cases that were disposed of could be reinstated.  DE didn't realize that.  State has no objection to extension if one can be had.  Court will do an extension to Court of Appeals until 9/30/16.  DE states should have Atty. Englund by 9/1/16 on board.
Return date on September 1, 2016 at 01:00 pm.

Defendant Matthew John Johnson in court with attorney Adam P Nero.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  State objects to motion of defense.  Attorney Nero advises court post conviction relief will be requesting to vacate the plea.  Request bond pending appeal.  Defendant has been in custody for 3 weeks on a 120 day sentence.  Defendant is employed.  State objects to motion as stated.  Cites State vs Gudenschwager, 1995 case.  Stay is not warranted.  IF lifted, State request $2500 cash bond with conditions.  Attorney Nero responds to State's argument.  Prior motion withdrawn by Attorney Nero filed by Defendant in January.  Attorney Nero request signature bond with conditions.  Court orders release upon appeal.  Court sets $250.00 CASH bond.  Conditions:    Not to oper MV w/out valid DL, absolute sobriety from alcohol and controlled substances.  Submit to chemical test if requested by law enforcement.    State request status hearing be set.  Telephone conference scheduled for March 14, 2016 at 09:00 am.
Return Date 11/19/14

Defendant Matthew John Johnson in court.  Dennis Joseph Ryan appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Court states case and State states appearances.  MH today on relief pending appeal filed by DE.  DE explains he just got the paperwork from the Court of Appeals yesterday.  Court explains his understanding of the matter to the DE.  DE responds.  State objects to a stay pending appeal and explains why.  Court addresses possible withdrawal of plea.  Atty Ryan feels the most fair thing would be to stay the sentence as requested so DE can talk to counsel to address the appeal process.  State doesn't object to a 60 day stay.  Court grants stay of sentence pending appeal.  That stay is for no more than 60 days pending appeal.  Court encourages the DE to proceed as quickly as possible as the stay won't go on past the 60 days w/o another motion.

Defendant Matthew John Johnson in court with attorney Brent W. Varner.  Sue Mueller appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Plea to Count 1.  Dismiss/read 14CF182 and Counts 2, 3 & 4.  Attorney Varner request sentencing date out 60 days.  State agrees and does not object.  Attorney Varner also advises the court the matter is stipulated at this time.  Court goes through all constitutional rights with defendant.  No victim notification requirements.  Court accepts the plea and finds the defendant guilty.  Matter set over for sentencing.
